content: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <feed xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom">  <title>Debian GNU/Linux System Administration Resources</title>  <subtitle>Tips for a Debian GNU/Linux System Administrator.</subtitle>  <link href="http://www.debian-administration.org/" />  <link rel="self" href="http://www.debian-administration.org/atom.xml" />  <updated>2015-03-12T17:16:01Z</updated>  <author>    <name>Steve Kemp</name>    <uri>http://www.debian-administration.org/</uri>  </author>  <icon>http://www.debian-administration.org/favicon.ico</icon>  <id>http://www.debian-administration.org/</id>      <entry>    <id>http://www.debian-administration.org/article/714/Using_the_rubocop_ruby_code_and_style_analyzer</id>    <title>Using the rubocop ruby code and style analyzer</title>    <link href="http://www.debian-administration.org/article/714/Using_the_rubocop_ruby_code_and_style_analyzer" />    <updated>2015-03-09T12:12:28Z</updated>    <summary type="html">If you're developing code that you expect others to read and work with then it is very important to pick a consistent style, and having a style-checker can make enforcing your choice much less painful.  Here we'll take a look at the <tt>rubocop</tt> analyzer for Ruby.</summary>    <author>     <name>Steve</name>     <uri>http://www.debian-administration.org/users/Steve</uri>    </author>   </entry>     <entry>    <id>http://www.debian-administration.org/article/713/Easily_working_with_multiple_repositories_git_hg_etc</id>    <title>Easily working with multiple repositories (git, hg, etc)</title>    <link href="http://www.debian-administration.org/article/713/Easily_working_with_multiple_repositories_git_hg_etc" />    <updated>2015-02-08T18:00:09Z</updated>    <summary type="html">There are situations where it is ueful to checkout multiple repositories, which might use different revision control systems, and operate upon them as a group.  This is what the <tt>mr</tt> tool was designed for.</summary>    <author>     <name>Steve</name>     <uri>http://www.debian-administration.org/users/Steve</uri>    </author>   </entry>     <entry>    <id>http://www.debian-administration.org/article/712/An_introduction_to_the_attic_backup_program</id>    <title>An introduction to the attic backup program</title>    <link href="http://www.debian-administration.org/article/712/An_introduction_to_the_attic_backup_program" />    <updated>2014-12-23T11:09:12Z</updated>    <summary type="html">Over the past year or two several new backup utilities have become popular.  These new tools tend to avoid the use of <tt>tar.gz</tt> files, and just store backups as collections of files.  Usually these storage areas are incrementally updated and avoid wasting space thanks to the detection of duplicate content.  Here we're going to look at one of them in particular "attic".</summary>    <author>     <name>Steve</name>     <uri>http://www.debian-administration.org/users/Steve</uri>    </author>   </entry>     <entry>    <id>http://www.debian-administration.org/article/711/A_brief_introduction_to_publish-subscribe_queuing_with_redis</id>    <title>A brief introduction to publish-subscribe queuing with redis</title>    <link href="http://www.debian-administration.org/article/711/A_brief_introduction_to_publish-subscribe_queuing_with_redis" />    <updated>2014-12-17T16:46:55Z</updated>    <summary type="html">In this brief article we'll demonstrate using Redis for a publish/subscribe system.  There are dedicated publish-subscribe platforms out there, but Redis is reasonably performant and essentially configuration-free.</summary>    <author>     <name>Steve</name>     <uri>http://www.debian-administration.org/users/Steve</uri>    </author>   </entry>     <entry>    <id>http://www.debian-administration.org/article/710/Setting_up_your_own_graphical_git-server_with_gitbucket</id>    <title>Setting up your own graphical git-server with gitbucket</title>    <link href="http://www.debian-administration.org/article/710/Setting_up_your_own_graphical_git-server_with_gitbucket" />    <updated>2014-10-14T09:18:20Z</updated>    <summary type="html">This article documents the process of configuring a git host, using <a href="https://github.com/takezoe/gitbucket">gitbucket</a>, which will give you a graphical interface to a collection of git repositories, accessible via any browser, along with support for groups, issues, and forks.</summary>    <author>     <name>Steve</name>     <uri>http://www.debian-administration.org/users/Steve</uri>    </author>   </entry>     <entry>    <id>http://www.debian-administration.org/article/709/Using_the_haproxy_load-balancer_for_increased_availability</id>    <title>Using the haproxy load-balancer for increased availability</title>    <link href="http://www.debian-administration.org/article/709/Using_the_haproxy_load-balancer_for_increased_availability" />    <updated>2014-08-27T14:12:27Z</updated>    <summary type="html"><tt>HAProxy</tt> is a TCP/HTTP load-balancer, allowing you to route incoming traffic destined for one address to a number of different back-ends.  The routing is very flexible and it can be a useful component of a high-availability setup.</summary>    <author>     <name>Steve</name>     <uri>http://www.debian-administration.org/users/Steve</uri>    </author>   </entry>     <entry>    <id>http://www.debian-administration.org/article/708/Automating_the_Debian_installer_with_PXE_and_preseeding</id>    <title>Automating the Debian installer with PXE and preseeding</title>    <link href="http://www.debian-administration.org/article/708/Automating_the_Debian_installer_with_PXE_and_preseeding" />    <updated>2014-08-23T12:34:13Z</updated>    <summary type="html">This article is designed to introduce the process of PXE-booting a host directly into the Debian installer, and then automating the installation via the Debian PreSeed configuration.  Both of these topics have been covered in the past, but not together - and we'll also include notes on testing this setup with KVM.</summary>    <author>     <name>Steve</name>     <uri>http://www.debian-administration.org/users/Steve</uri>    </author>   </entry>     <entry>    <id>http://www.debian-administration.org/article/707/Disabling_Apache_logging_of_particular_requests</id>    <title>Disabling Apache logging of particular requests</title>    <link href="http://www.debian-administration.org/article/707/Disabling_Apache_logging_of_particular_requests" />    <updated>2014-08-07T10:26:13Z</updated>    <summary type="html">I've got a webserver which runs a particular service, and that service is sufficiently interesting and important that I run monitoring probes against it every 30 seconds.  Those particular requests clutter my logs, and here is a brief note on how to avoid that clutter.</summary>    <author>     <name>Steve</name>     <uri>http://www.debian-administration.org/users/Steve</uri>    </author>   </entry>     <entry>    <id>http://www.debian-administration.org/article/706/GNU_Make_4.0_released_including_support_for_plugins</id>    <title>GNU Make 4.0 released, including support for plugins</title>    <link href="http://www.debian-administration.org/article/706/GNU_Make_4.0_released_including_support_for_plugins" />    <updated>2014-05-11T11:31:30Z</updated>    <summary type="html">The new upload of GNU Make 4.0 recently reached Debian's unstable distribution, and has also migrated to the testing distribution, currently codenamed "jessie".  GNU Make 4.0 brings in several new features, perhaps the most interesting of which is support for the use of plugins.</summary>    <author>     <name>Steve</name>     <uri>http://www.debian-administration.org/users/Steve</uri>    </author>   </entry>     <entry>    <id>http://www.debian-administration.org/article/705/Debian_7_7.5_released</id>    <title>Debian 7: 7.5 released</title>    <link href="http://www.debian-administration.org/article/705/Debian_7_7.5_released" />    <updated>2014-04-26T18:27:21Z</updated>    <summary type="html">The Debian project is pleased to announce the fifth update of its stable distribution Debian 7 (codename "wheezy"). This update mainly adds corrections for security problems to the stable release, along with a few adjustments for serious problems. Security advisories were already published separately and are referenced where available.</summary>    <author>     <name>ajt</name>     <uri>http://www.debian-administration.org/users/ajt</uri>    </author>   </entry>    </feed>
